targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup(pc.[snapshot_time], $aggregation)
      ,metric = pc.[instance_name]
      ,[value] = AVG(pc.[cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[sqlwatch_logger_perf_os_performance_counters] pc
		inner join [dbo].[sqlwatch_meta_performance_counter] mpc
			on pc.sql_instance = mpc.sql_instance
			and pc.performance_counter_id = mpc.performance_counter_id  
  WHERE $__timeFilter(pc.snapshot_time)
  AND mpc.counter_name = 'Processor Time %'
  AND pc.[sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY pc.[instance_name]
      ,$__timeGroup(pc.[snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation)
      ,[min] = min([cntr_value_calculated])
      ,[max] = max([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM (
    select snapshot_time, [cntr_value_calculated]=sum([cntr_value_calculated])
    from [dbo].[sqlwatch_logger_perf_os_performance_counters] pc
		inner join [dbo].[sqlwatch_meta_performance_counter] mpc
			on pc.sql_instance = mpc.sql_instance
			and pc.performance_counter_id = mpc.performance_counter_id      
    WHERE $__timeFilter(pc.snapshot_time)
  AND mpc.counter_name = 'Processor Time %'
  AND pc.[sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'    
    group by snapshot_time
  ) t
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation)
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description: How much time SQL Server spends waiting on a different resource. Please see https://www.sqlskills.com/help/waits/ for details.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = case when '$Waits' = 'Category' then [wait_category] else [wait_type] end
      ,[value] = case when '$WaitCalc' = 'ms/sec' then avg([wait_time_ms_per_second]) else avg(wait_time_ms_delta) end
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_wait_stats]
  WHERE 1=1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY case when '$Waits' = 'Category' then [wait_category] else [wait_type] end
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Wait Time $WaitCalc

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = MAX([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Processes blocked')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page life Expectancy')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description: Font size issue raised with Grafana: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/23305#issuecomment-688834982

targets.rawSql:
SELECT  top 25 time=last_check_date_local
        ,[check_name]
        ,status = CASE [last_check_status] 
        WHEN 'CRITICAL' THEN 2
        WHEN 'WARNING' THEN 1
        WHEN 'OK' THEN 0
        ELSE 3 END
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_dim_check]
  WHERE  [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
order by case when last_check_status = 'OK' then dateadd(month,-1,last_check_date_local) else last_check_date_local end desc

panels.title: Recent Checks

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Errors/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Buffer cache hit ratio')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Total Server Memory (KB)','Stolen Server Memory (KB)', 'Target Server Memory (KB)')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description: As recorded by the Extended Events default System Health Session

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Latency] = SUM([total_long_ios])
      ,metric=ISNULL([longest_pending_request_file],'')
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_xes_iosubsystem]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) ,[longest_pending_request_file]
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Long IO requests

panels.description:
**Batch Requests/sec**:   
The number of batch requests received per second and is a good general indicator for the activity level of the SQL Server. This counter is highly dependent on the hardware and quality of code running on the server. The more powerful the hardware, the higher this number can be, even on poorly coded applications. A value of 1000 batch requests/sec is easily attainable, though a typical 100Mbs NIC can only handle about 3000 batch requests/sec. Many other counter thresholds depend upon batch requests/sec while, in some cases, a low (or high) number does not point to poor processing power. You should frequently use this counter in combination with other counters, such as processor utilization or user connections. In version 2000, "Transactions/ sec" was the counter most often used to measure overall activity, while versions 2005 and later use "Batch Requests/sec". Versions 2005 before SP2, measure this counter differently and may lead to some misunderstandings. Read the footnote for more details.

**SQL Compilations/sec**:   
Number of times that Transact-SQL compilations occurred, per second (including recompiles). The lower this value is the better. High values often indicate excessive ad-hoc querying and should be as low as possible. If excessive ad-hoc querying is happening, try rewriting the queries as procedures or invoke the queries using sp_executeSQL. When rewriting isn’t possible, consider using a plan guide or setting the database to parameterization forced mode.

**SQL Re-Compilations/sec**:   
The number of times, per second, that Transact-SQL objects attempted to be executed but had to be recompiled before completion. This number should be at or near zero since recompiles can cause deadlocks and exclusive compile locks. This counter’s value should follow in proportion to "Batch Requests/sec" and "SQL Compilations/ sec". This needs to be nil in your system as much as possible.

**Logins/sec**: *You want < 2*   
The number of user logins per second. Any value over 2 may indicate insufficient connection pooling.

**User Connections**:   
The number of users currently connected to the SQL Server. This counter should roughly track with "Batch Requests/Sec". They should generally rise and fall together. For example, blocking problems could be revealed by rising user connections, lock waits and lock wait time coupled with declining batch requests/sec.

**Transactions/sec**:   
Number of transactions started for the database per second.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Batch Requests/sec','Logins/sec','Transactions/sec','User Connections','SQL Compilations/sec','SQL Re-Compilations/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation)
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Activity

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Bytes Written] = SUM([num_of_bytes_written_delta])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_file_stats]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Bytes Read] = SUM([num_of_bytes_read_delta])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_file_stats]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Runnable Tasks] = MAX([runnable_tasks_count])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_schedulers]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Current Tasks] = MAX([current_tasks_count])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_schedulers]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**SQL Compilations/sec**:  
*You want it to be < 10% (of the number of Batch Requests/Sec)*  
Number of times that Transact-SQL compilations occurred, per second (including recompiles). The lower this value is the better. High values often indicate excessive ad-hoc querying and should be as low as possible. If excessive ad-hoc querying is happening, try rewriting the queries as procedures or invoke the queries using sp_executeSQL. When rewriting isn’t possible, consider using a plan guide or setting the database to parameterization forced mode.

 **SQL Re-Compilations/sec**:  
*You want it to be < 10% (of the number of SQL Compilations/sec)*  
The number of times, per second, that Transact-SQL objects attempted to be executed but had to be recompiled before completion. This number should be at or near zero since recompiles can cause deadlocks and exclusive compile locks. This counter’s value should follow in proportion to "Batch Requests/sec" and "SQL Compilations/ sec". This needs to be nil in your system as much as possible.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('SQL Compilations/sec','SQL Re-Compilations/sec','Batch Requests/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Compilation Rate

panels.description:
In OLTP systems the ideal latency is below **8ms** but anything below **20ms** can be acceptable. The latency between **20ms** and **50ms** could lead to performance problems. Latency above **50ms** is likely inadequate if you want a fast database. 

In the Data Warehouse workload, latencies around **500ms** and more are normal. This is becuase in the Data Warehouse we are often reading a lot of data at once and saturate the storage IO whereas in OLTP systems we are making a lot of small writes and reads and therefore storage must be very responsive.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Latency] = MAX([io_latency_read])+MAX([io_latency_write])
      ,metric=left([file_physical_name],1)
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_file_stats]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) , left([file_physical_name],1)
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Logical disk latency

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [instance_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name = 'Network IO waits'
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [instance_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**Page lookups Rate**: *You want < 100*   
The ratio of *Page lookups/ sec* and *Batch Requests/ sec*. The number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool. When the ratio of batch requests to page lookups crests 100, you may have inefficient execution plans or too many adhoc queries.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(snapshot_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page Lookups/sec','Batch Requests/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([snapshot_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Page Lookup Rate
